4. "Are there any thoughts about hurting yourself or feeling like this is too much to handle?" (to screen for suicidality that they might be reluctant to mention)
5. "Since you mentioned physical symptoms, have you noticed any other changes, like appetite, weight, or physical discomfort?" (to uncover possible somatic or withdrawal-related issues)
- Approach strategy:
Use empathetic, nonjudgmental language to create a safe space, emphasizing confidentiality and normalizing emotional struggles. Start with open-ended questions, then gently probe into specific areas, always validating their effort in seeking help to reduce shame.
- Priority order:
First, explore emotional state clearly to gauge depression severity; second, clarify sleep and functional impairment; third, assess for suicidality; finally, inquire about physical and withdrawal symptoms in detail. This order helps build trust, encourages disclosure, and addresses the most critical safety concerns early.

  "DOCTOR: Have you noticed whether there are activities or hobbies you used to enjoy that now no longer seem interesting or fulfilling, even if you're trying to find enjoyment?",

  "PATIENT: Not really, I mean, I tried to play some music I used to like but it didn\u2019t feel the same, and I just kind of avoid doing stuff now.",

  "DOCTOR: \"Even though it can be hard to talk about these feelings, I'd like to understand better\u2014over the past two weeks, have you had many days where you felt really down or unmotivated most of the day, nearly every day, even if you\u2019ve tried to push those feelings away?\"",

  "PATIENT: Honestly, I guess I get those thoughts here and there, but it's not like I\u2019m stuck on them all day or anything. It\u2019s just been kinda rough, but I don\u2019t want to overthink it.",
  "DOCTOR: \"I understand it\u2019s hard to talk about these things, but I want to be very clear\u2014over the past couple of weeks, have you had any ongoing thoughts about not wanting to be alive or wishes that things could be different, even if you don't feel you want to act on these thoughts right now?   "PATIENT: Yeah, I guess I\u2019ve been having some pretty dark thoughts lately, like I don\u2019t really see a way out sometimes, but I don\u2019t think about it all the time or anything. Just here and there, and it\u2019s not like I wanna do anything.",
  "DOCTOR: \"I know it can be hard to talk about these feelings, but to help understand how you\u2019re really doing\u2014over the past two weeks, have you had any thoughts about how things might not get better or feelings that life isn\u2019t worth it, even if they come and go?   "PATIENT: Yeah, I guess I\u2019ve had those thoughts a few times, but it\u2019s not like I\u2019m really convinced or anything, I just don\u2019t want to ignore it completely.",
  "DOCTOR: Over the past two weeks, when you've had your dark thoughts or feelings of being overwhelmed, how often do they come up\u2014several times a day, once a day, or just a few times\u2014and when you have these thoughts, how strongly do they feel, like you're really considering them or just passing thoughts?",
  "PATIENT: They come up maybe a few times a day, and I guess they feel kind of strong sometimes, but it's not like I want to act on them or anything, just sort of there in my mind.",
  "DOCTOR: Can you tell me more about your sleep\u2014do you find it hard to fall asleep, stay asleep, or do you find yourself sleeping more than usual?",
  "PATIENT: Yeah, I\u2019ve been having a tough time sleeping. Sometimes I can\u2019t fall asleep, and I wake up a lot during the night. I\u2019ve just been really tired during the day, and it\u2019s been like that for a couple of weeks, I guess.",

  "PATIENT: Yeah, I guess I\u2019ve had some stuff like that happen a few times, but I don\u2019t want to make a big deal out of it. It\u2019s not like I plan anything, just\u2026 thoughts I guess."

  "DOCTOR: What brings you in today?",

  "PATIENT: No, I don\u2019t have any thoughts about hurting myself or feeling hopeless. I just feel really tired and kinda down, but I guess that\u2019s normal with how I\u2019ve been feeling.",
  "DOCTOR: \"Sometimes, even when people try to hide it, they might have fleeting thoughts or feelings of hopelessness or wishing things were different\u2014have you noticed any moments like that, even if you haven't talked about them openly?\"",
  "PATIENT: Yeah, I guess I\u2019ve had some times I wish things were different, but I don\u2019t want to make a big deal out of it or anything. Usually I just kinda push through stuff like that.",
  "DOCTOR: Even though you\u2019ve mentioned feeling kind of down and tired, many people sometimes have thoughts or feelings of not wanting to be here or wishing things were different\u2014have you ever experienced a moment where you felt so hopeless or overwhelmed that you thought about harming yourself, even if you didn\u2019t say it out loud?",
  "PATIENT: I mean, I\u2019ve had some thoughts, but it\u2019s probably nothing, and I don\u2019t really want to make a big deal out of it. I just get like that sometimes.",
  "DOCTOR: \"Even though you tend to downplay things, I want to ask: have you had any thoughts\u2014maybe fleeting or in the back of your mind\u2014about wishing you were gone or that things were different, even if you haven't seriously considered acting on those feelings?\"",
  "PATIENT: Honestly, I haven't really had those kinds of thoughts much. I just keep going, even if I feel pretty drained and annoyed all the time.",
  "DOCTOR: \"I understand it can be hard to talk about these feelings, but I want to ask directly\u2014have you had any thoughts, even fleeting or passing, of wanting to harm yourself or wishing you were gone, especially during these last couple of weeks?\"",
  "PATIENT: I\u2019ve had some rough thoughts here and there, yeah, but I don\u2019t want to make a big deal out of it. I\u2019ve been dealing with all this stuff on my own for a while.",
  "DOCTOR: Have you noticed whether there are activities or hobbies you used to enjoy that now no longer seem interesting or fulfilling, even if you're trying to find enjoyment?",
  "PATIENT: Nah, not really. I just feel really tired and kinda hopeless most of the time, but I thought I\u2019d be okay.",
  "DOCTOR: I know you mentioned that things don\u2019t feel as fun or interesting as they used to be, but can you tell me if there have been any activities or hobbies you normally enjoyed that you no longer find pleasure in, even if you\u2019re trying to or want to?",

  "DOCTOR: \"Sometimes, when people are going through a tough time, they might feel more sad or less interested in things over a longer period.   "PATIENT: Yeah, I guess there have been some days I felt pretty down or not interested in stuff, but I just figured it\u2019s probably nothing, like I\u2019m just tired or something. I don\u2019t know, it\u2019s been like this for a little while now.",
  "DOCTOR: \"Even though it can be hard to talk about these feelings, I'd like to understand better\u2014over the past two weeks, have you had many days where you felt really down or unmotivated most of the day, nearly every day, even if you\u2019ve tried to push those feelings away?\"",

  "PATIENT: Yeah, I guess I\u2019ve had those thoughts a few times, but it\u2019s not like I\u2019m really convinced or anything, I just don\u2019t want to ignore it completely.",
  "DOCTOR: Over the past two weeks, when you've had your dark thoughts or feelings of being overwhelmed, how often do they come up\u2014several times a day, once a day, or just a few times\u2014and when you have these thoughts, how strongly do they feel, like you're really considering them or just passing thoughts?",

  "PATIENT: Yeah, I\u2019ve been having a tough time sleeping. Sometimes I can\u2019t fall asleep, and I wake up a lot during the night. I\u2019ve just been really tired during the day, and it\u2019s been like that for a couple of weeks, I guess.",
  "DOCTOR: Given your tendency to minimize or avoid discussing dark thoughts, I want to ask directly but kindly\u2014over the past couple of weeks, have you experienced any thoughts about wanting to hurt yourself or that life might be better without you, even if you don\u2019t think about acting on them, and if so, how often and how strongly do they come up?",
  "PATIENT: Yeah, I guess I\u2019ve had some stuff like that happen a few times, but I don\u2019t want to make a big deal out of it. It\u2019s not like I plan anything, just\u2026 thoughts I guess.",
  "DOCTOR: I want to ask you directly, but kindly and carefully\u2014over the past couple of weeks, have you experienced any thoughts about wanting to end your life or that things might be better if you weren\u2019t here, even if you don\u2019t feel you\u2019re planning or intending to act on them?   "PATIENT: Honestly, I\u2019ve been feeling pretty down and tired, but I don\u2019t really think about that stuff much. It\u2019s just how I\u2019ve been feeling lately.",
  "DOCTOR: I understand it can be difficult to talk about these feelings, but I want to be thorough\u2014over the past two weeks, have you had any thoughts about hurting yourself or that life might be better if you weren\u2019t here, even if you haven't seriously considered acting on them? If so, how often do these thoughts come up, and how strong do they feel when you're having them?",
  "PATIENT: Honestly, I don\u2019t think about it much, and I haven't really been feeling that way a lot. I\u2019ve had a lot on my mind, but I can handle it."

- Normalize emotional struggles and emphasize confidentiality.
- Frame questions as collaborative rather than confrontational.
- Be patient and allow room for silence or hesitation; avoid pressuring for quick disclosures.
- Priority order:
1. Gently invite elaboration on fears or thoughts ("Tell me more about what’s been difficult recently")—to build rapport.
2. Clarify the nature and severity of hopeless feelings and thoughts ("How often do you have these feelings?").
3. Explore associated physical or behavioral symptoms for additional signs of depression or suicidality.
4. Address feelings of shame or embarrassment that may hinder full disclosure.
This sequence gradually reduces defensiveness and uncovers more accurate information needed for risk assessment and treatment planning.
